byline.contributor: Benjamin Mueller and Kate Pastor contributed reporting, and Susan C. Beachy contributed research.
byline.original: By WINNIE HU and NOAH REMNICK

abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio and other officials are attempting to vigorously fight city's biggest outbreak of Legionnaires' disease; seven people have died in South Bronx since July 10, with 86 confirmed cases and expectation that more will be reported; city is criticized for belated response to risks of cooling towers in fostering and spreading the disease.
lead_paragraph: Since the outbreak that gave Legionnaires’ disease its name, water-cooling towers have been identified as prime breeding grounds, but the city has done little to address the risks.

headline.main: A Belated Look at New York’s Cooling Towers, Prime Suspect in Legionnaires’ Outbreak
headline.print_headline: Belated Focus on Prime Suspect in an Outbreak
